text.front:
Coevaporation of Cu 2 ZnSnSe 4 thin films
Alex Redinger a͒ and Susanne Siebentritt
Laboratoire de photovoltaique, Université du Luxembourg, 41, rue du Brill, L-4422 Belvaux, Luxembourg
͑Received 1 June 2010; accepted 1 August 2010; published online 2 September 2010͒
Cu 2 ZnSnSe 4 thin films grown by coevaporation are investigated in a wide temperature range and for
different Se partial pressures during growth. At temperatures higher than 350°C Sn is
re-evaporating as SnSe from the surface whereas Zn is lost at temperatures higher than 430°C.
Moreover the Se partial pressure dramatically changes the Zn and Sn concentrations in the resulting
film. Interrupted processes at 380°C show that single-stage coevaporation intrinsically induces a
secondary phase at the substrate/film interface. © 2010 American Institute of Physics.
͓doi:10.1063/1.3483760͔
text.body:
The compound semiconductors Cu 2 ZnSnSe 4 ͑CZTSe͒
and Cu 2 ZnSnS 4 ͑CZTS͒ are promising candidates for the
next generation thin film solar cells. Compared to the current
high efficiency thin film solar cells Cu͑In, Ga͒Se 2 and CdTe
they are composed of elements with a higher abundance in
the Earth crust and a reduced toxicity.
A prerequisite for high efficiency solar cells is the
growth of single phase material which, according to theoret-
ical calculations is very demanding. The chemical potential
region for stable single phase material without unwanted sec-
ondary or ternary phases is very small. 1
The highest solar cell efficiency so far has been reported
by Todorov et al. 2 They used a hybrid solution-particle ap-
proach and achieved an efficiency of 9.7% from a mixed
Cu 2 ZnSn͑S,Se͒ 4 compound. The highest efficiency from a
vacuum based process has been reported by Katagiri et al. 3
in the case of CZTS ͑6.7%͒ and Zoppi et al. 4 in the case of
CZTSe ͑3.2%͒. In both cases sputtering has been employed
to produce a precursor ͓͑Cu,ZnS,SnS͒ ͑Ref. 3͒ or ͑Cu,Zn,Sn͒
͑Ref. 4͔͒ which has been subsequently annealed in a chalco-
gen atmosphere.
Astonishingly, the coevaporation technique, which is ex-
tremely useful in the case of Cu͑In, Ga͒Se 2 , shows so far
poor solar cell results and has been used rarely. 5-7 One rea-
son might be the loss of Sn at temperatures higher than
400°C. 5,8,9 It has been shown that this loss is due to the
formation of SnS ͑SnSe͒ ͑Refs. 5 and 9͒ which has a much
higher vapor pressure than Sn at the usual substrate tempera-
tures. Annealing in vacuum even leads to the decomposition
of CZTS at temperatures higher than 550°C due to SnS
re-evaporation. 9 However a CZTSe coevaporation process is
highly desirable since then the Cu͑In, Ga͒Se 2 module pro-
duction technology can be adopted without any need of fur-
ther development.
We have therefore systematically investigated the
growth of CZTSe at different temperatures and evaporation
conditions. Especially the influence of the Se partial pressure
during growth turns out to be very important. Moreover a
sequence of experiments where the process has been inter-
rupted reveals the complexity of CZTSe growth by coevapo-
ration.
The growth of CZTSe thin films has been carried out in
a molecular beam epitaxy system with a base pressure of
5 ϫ 10 −8 mbar without bake-out. Thermal evaporation of Cu,
Zn, Sn, and Se is accomplished from effusion cells. The sub-
strate temperature is regulated via a thermocouple, which is
situated in the vicinity of the sample holder and the surface
temperature is monitored with a pyrometer. Commercially
available molybdenum coated soda lime glass is used as sub-
strate. The temperatures indicated below correspond to the
substrate temperatures recorded with the pyrometer ͑cali-
brated to the emissivity of the Mo-coated substrate͒. The
evaporation rates are measured with a quartz crystal monitor,
a Bayert Alpert pressure gauge, and an electron impact emis-
sion spectroscopy system. In all deposition processes the
metal fluxes have been kept constant ͑Ϸ1-2 Å/s͒ and the
relative variations between experiments are smaller than
10%. Elemental concentrations are deduced from an energy
dispersive x-ray ͑EDX͒ analysis system attached to a scan-
ning electron microscope ͑SEM͒. The acceleration voltage
has been set to 20 kV in all measurements. Phase analysis
has been carried out by x-ray diffraction ͑XRD͒.
The temperature dependent growth experiments have
been carried out in an excess Se atmosphere. A Se partial
pressure of 4 ϫ 10 −6 Torr measured at the substrate position,
constant Cu, Zn, Sn evaporation rates, and a constant process
time of 90 min have been used. The elemental concentrations
as deduced from EDX measurements are shown in Fig. 1 in

a temperature range between 320 and 515°C. The results
can be divided into three regimes. The low temperature re-
gime ͑I͒ below 350°C shows no significant variations in the
elemental concentrations with temperature. The films are
slightly Cu poor ͓Cu/ ͑Zn+ Sn͒ = 0.8͔ and Zn rich ͓Zn/ Sn
= 1.08͔ which according to the present record cells 2 is ideal
for solar cells. The temperature independence of the elemen-
tal compositions reveals that material losses due to re-
evaporation are not significant in this temperature range.
At 380°C the Sn signal decreases slightly. The decrease
becomes more pronounced at 405°C where the Sn concen-
tration drops by 30% compared to region ͑I͒ whereas the Zn
concentration stays roughly constant. The decrease in Sn is
accompanied with a decrease in Se. Increasing the tempera-
ture to 430°C leads to a complete Sn loss. The Zn concen-
tration, as depicted in Fig. 1, appears to increase at this point.
However this change is due to a change in film thickness. As
will be shown later, at temperatures higher than 350°C a
ZnSe secondary phase is present at the back of the film. Due
to the reduced thickness the probing electrons of the SEM
are sensitive to this secondary phase which increases the ap-
parent Zn concentration compared to region ͑I͒. Region ͑II͒
is therefore characterized by Sn losses.
A further increase to 515°C ͑region III͒ leads to a com-
plete loss of Zn and Sn. The resulting film consists only of
Cu 2−x Se.
The measurements presented in Fig. 1 show that, de-
pending on the temperature, up to three of the four elements
are volatile which makes the growth of uniform CZTSe with
a desired stoichiometry a difficult task. Before discussing the
results, a second set of experiments is presented. Here the Se
partial pressure during growth is varied at a constant sub-
strate temperature of 380°C, constant metal fluxes and with
a constant process time of 90 min. This temperature regime
͓labeled ͑II͒ in Fig. 1͔ corresponds to the intermediate case
where the incorporation of Sn is still possible.
Figure 2 shows the elemental concentrations in the films
deduced from EDX as a function of the Se pressure present
during growth. Deposition of the metals without the chalco-
gen does not lead to any incorporation of Zn. XRD reveals
that the film consists almost exclusively out of Cu x Sn y al-
loys. Increasing the Se pressure to 5 ϫ 10 −7 Torr leads to a
strong decrease in the Sn concentration. Zn is still not incor-
porated and the film consists mainly out of Cu 2−x Se
and some remaining Cu x Sn y alloys. The film thickness
is extremely small ͑Ϸ200 nm͒ since no Zn and only little
Sn is bound. Only after increasing the Se pressure to
1 ϫ 10 −6 Torr can Zn be incorporated. The film is composed
of Cu 2−x Se and ZnSe while Sn phases cannot be detected in
XRD. A further increase in the Se pressure ͓3 ϫ 10 −6 and
4 ϫ 10 −6 Torr͔ results in an increase in the Sn concentration.
The film thicknesses increase by one order of magnitude
compared to the film grown at 5 ϫ 10 −7 Torr. XRD of these
films reveals that at least part of the film has crystallized in
the stannite type CZTSe. 10
The measurements show that for fixed Zn, Cu, and Sn
evaporation rates, the film thickness changes by more than
one order of magnitude and Zn and Sn concentrations de-
pend strongly on the Se partial pressure. Already at this point
we can conclude that a prerequisite for control of the com-
position is an accurate monitoring of the Se pressure since it
influences dramatically the incorporation of Sn and Zn in the
film.
The incorporation of an element proceeds in three steps.
First the atom adsorbs to the surface, followed by surface
diffusion. After some time the adatom nucleates or re-
evaporates. The adsorption rate of each element i is propor-
tional to the flux of impinging particles f i which is linked to
the equilibrium vapor pressure p i and temperature T i of the
source via the following Hertz-Knudsen equation: f i = p i
ϫ ͑2mk B T i ͒ −0.5 . 11,12 After adsorption the atoms diffuse over
the surface performing a random walk with a diffusion coef-
ficient D i . After a certain lifetime i the atom desorbs. Both
processes follow an Arrhenius law as it is known for ther-
mally activated processes. Diffusion coefficient and lifetime
define the characteristic length l i via Eq. ͑1͒ as follows:
l i = ͱ D i i .
͑1͒
In evaporation or condensation l i describes the covered dis-
tance of an adatom prior to desorption. 13 Due to the com-
plexity of the system none of the kinetic parameters for
CZTSe are available. In order to describe the processes on a
qualitative level we use the equilibrium situation and link the
lifetime of the adatoms to the partial pressure of the elements
at a temperature T. A low partial pressure corresponds to a
large energy barrier for desorption resulting in a long life-
time.
Equation ͑1͒ can now be used to describe the experimen-
tal observations on a qualitative level. Deposition without Se
leads to the incorporation of Sn and Cu in the film due to
their low vapor pressure at 380°C. They exhibit long char-
acteristic lengths l i and Cu x Sn y alloys form. Zn however is
not incorporated due to the large vapor pressure at 380°C
͓cf. Table I͔. Cu-Zn and Sn-Zn alloys can be excluded by
XRD analysis. Introducing Se into the system leads prefer-

entially to the formation of Cu 2−x Se and SnSe. The formation
of ZnSe is still suppressed since the characteristic lengths l Sn
and l Cu are much larger than l Zn . As a result Cu and Sn
consumes all the available Se, and Zn desorbs. However, the
formation of SnSe, which has a high vapor pressure ͓cf.
Table I͔, leads to a reduction in Sn in the film. A further
increase in the Se partial pressure leads to a complete loss of
Sn while Zn can now be found in the film. The high Se
supersaturation is necessary to remove all Sn and to compen-
sate for the small l Zn . ZnSe forms which exhibits a negligible
vapor pressure at 380°C. The film consists almost entirely
of Cu 2−x Se and ZnSe. A further increase in Se leads again to
an increase in the Sn concentration. This is at first glance not
intuitive since a higher Se overpressure should enhance the
formation of SnSe and therefore inhibit the Sn incorporation.
In order to clarify this, Fig. 3 shows the temporal evolution
of the growth at T = 380°C and at a constant Se partial pres-
sure of p Se =4ϫ 10 −6 Torr ͓the largest Se pressure shown in
Fig. 2͔. It is clearly visible that the incorporation of Sn does
not start right from the beginning of the experiment but only
after some induction time. At the beginning a mixed
Cu 2−x Se/ ZnSe thin film grows. After approximately 15 min
which corresponds to roughly 300 nm, Sn can be identified
by EDX. Apparently the presence of a large amount of
Cu 2−x Se and ZnSe fosters the Sn incorporation in the film to
form CZTSe. The behavior is probably caused by a change
in the desorption rate on the ZnSe/ Cu 2−x Se grains compared
to the Mo substrate. An experiment at 360°C where only Sn
and Se are evaporated on Mo does not lead to any conden-
sation of SnSe.
One could now assume that the Cu 2−x Se and ZnSe grown
during the first 15 min is consumed and a homogeneous
CZTSe film results. However this is not the case. At 380°C
the diffusion coefficient of ZnSe is too small and as a con-
sequence a thin ZnSe secondary phase remains at the Mo/
CZTSe interface ͑confirmed by cross sectional SEM map-
ping, secondary ion mass spectrometry ͑SIMS͒, and Raman
measurements͒. The diffusion of Cu 2−x Se is already large
enough since no Cu related secondary phase could be found
at the back of the absorber.
From the previous discussion we are now able to explain
the remaining open questions in the temperature dependent
series ͓cf. Fig. 1͔. The increased Zn concentration when re-
ducing the film thickness arises from the ZnSe at the back of
the film as depicted in Fig. 3. The loss of Zn at 515°C is
also clear from the above discussion since the supersatura-
tion of Se decreases with increasing temperature which at a
certain point reduces the Zn incorporation.
We conclude that a simple coevaporation process at tem-
peratures higher then 350°C leads to Zn and Sn losses
which depend strongly on the Se partial pressure. The com-
plicated reactions lead to secondary phases and an accurate
control of the stoichiometry is difficult.
